title: Despite animated disagreements, Nationals refuse to pin Game 5 loss on umpire
text:
USA TODAY

WASHINGTON — Donald Trump may have received the most ornery ovation at Nationals Park on Sunday, but home plate umpire Lance Barksdale gave the president a run for his money.

Barksdale’s strike zone induced many a groan from the crowd throughout Washington’s 7-1 loss to the Houston Astros in Game 5 of the World Series. The apex of the distress occurred on the final pitch of the seventh inning with the Nationals trailing by three runs, as Gerrit Cole’s 110th offering of the night caught the up-and-away portion of the zone – in Barksdale’s eyes.

The 3-2 pitch to Nationals outfielder Victor Robles was indeed off the plate, but Barksdale punched him out, abbreviating the Nationals’ most meaningful "rally" of the night. Instead of walking to first base with Yan Gomes due up as the tying run, Robles incredulously turned toward Barksdale and then the dugout.

For as much outrage it caused among the 43,910 fans on hand, the Nats’ dugout was equally incensed. Multiple players and coaches climbed to the top step to voice their displeasure with the call, with manager Dave Martinez among the most animated.

The emotion from the Nationals skipper had been brewing. In the sixth, reliever Tanner Rainey and catcher Yan Gomes assumed they’d rung up Michael Brantley with a fastball at the knees. Gomes began to throw the ball around the horn, but no strike three call came.

“Wake up, c’mon let’s go,” Martinez can be heard barking from the dugout. “It’s the World Series! Wake up!”

After the game, Martinez refused to complain about the umpiring.

"I will not ever sit here and criticize an umpire," he said. "I've known Lance for a very long time and he's really good. ... I know there were some choice words but that's just in the heat of the moment. But like I said, they're doing their job, and they do it really well. That's why they're an umpire in the World Series. "

BOO BIRDS:President Donald Trump's World Series visit may be his last – for good reason

NATIONALS: Washington on the ropes after third straight loss

The rest of the Nationals clubhouse followed their skipper's lead on the matter.

“Lance did not lose us the game tonight," first baseman Ryan Zimmerman said. "Gerrit Cole beat us. I think that’s the best way to put it. I’ve known Lance for a very long time, he’s a really good guy and a good umpire.

"If you want to talk about the strike zone and stuff, you can go ask him. But I don’t think anyone should blame Lance what happened here tonight."

The closest any National came to criticizing Barksdale was starter Joe Ross' admission he believed an 0-2 slider to Astros shortstop Carlos Correa in the fourth inning was strike three. Barksdale ruled it a ball, Correa fought off the next three pitches and drilled the seventh pitch of the at-bat over the left-field wall to make it 4-0.

"I feel like as far as baseball goes, something small happens, then seems like later that at-bat always something big follows up," Ross said. "Unfortunately, that’s how it went.”

Gomes, who had as good a view as anyone in the ballpark, said looking back won't help the Nationals win the next two games.

"Frustrating? Sure, but that's a hindsight thing," Gomes said. "It’s one of those things – everyone’s human out there. We don’t have the little box that everyone sees (on television).

"I’m not gonna talk about the umpires or anything like that. Everyone’s human, we’re out there trying to do our best jobs."

description: Home plate umpire Lance Barskdale made several calls the Washington Nationals disagreed with during Game 5 of the World Series, and they let him know.
